title: 105_hr1588
content: The "United Nations Accountability Act of 1997" prohibits the payment of arrearages to the United Nations until reforms are certified by the President and approved by Congress. This certification is required for funds appropriated for contributions to international organizations or peacekeeping. The certification in section 2 requires the President to certify to Congress that the United Nations has implemented reforms including lowering the assessed payment of the US to 20% of the UN budget or reformulating each member state's assessed level based on their share of the world gross national product. Additionally, the UN must have a code of conduct for all employees. The Secretary General and other UN officials are prohibited from engaging in outside business activities, providing access to UN procurement contracts, or accepting bribes. The Office of Inspector General of the United Nations has been strengthened to conduct independent audits, inspections, and investigations. The United Nations has an inspector general appointed by the General Assembly for a 3-year term based on integrity and expertise in various fields. The inspector general can only be removed for cause by the Secretary General with the approval of the General Assembly, and is authorized to conduct investigations and reports. The United Nations inspector general is empowered to conduct investigations, access relevant records, and have direct access to officials. Procedures are in place to protect the identity of employees reporting complaints or disclosing information. The United Nations has fully implemented procedures to ensure compliance with recommendations of the inspector general, required annual reports to be issued, and committed to providing sufficient budgetary resources for the office of the inspector general. Employee protection within the United Nations grievance system has been reformed to allow for reporting complaints and disclosing information. The United Nations grievance system has been reformed to allow employees to hire outside counsel for grievances. Civil lawyers and judges should understand that UN officials' immunity only applies to official duties. Employees can exit the grievance process and sue in civil court if needed. Additionally, procurement reforms now require 30 days prior notification. The United Nations procurement reforms now require at least 30 days prior notification for bid proposals over $100,000 and public announcements for contract awards over $100,000. Whistleblower protection is also provided, prohibiting punitive actions for contractors who challenge contract awards. The United Nations has implemented whistleblower protection for employees, ensuring safeguards against retaliation for reporting fraud or mismanagement. Additionally, a no-growth budget has been adopted for the 2000-2001 biennium, with no nominal increase in expenditures. The United Nations has downsized authorized employment positions by at least 10% and imposed a salary freeze with limited annual increases tied to the US consumer price index. The United Nations requires annual review and reauthorization of peacekeeping missions by the Security Council, and the US Department of Defense is reimbursed for peacekeeping expenditures. The United Nations reimburses the US Department of Defense for voluntary contributions to peacekeeping missions. An agreement between the UN and the US allows for reimbursement for future contributions. The US and the UN have resolved arrearages in assessed contributions. Member states can be nominated to the Security Council through regional groups. The United Nations has abandoned efforts to establish international taxes or fees. They do not interfere with religious beliefs, culture, or traditions unless necessary for human rights protection. Congressional approval is required for the presidential certification. The term "joint resolution" refers to a resolution enacted within a 30-legislative day period approving the President's certification on UN reforms. The resolution described in subsection (a) introduced in the Senate shall be referred to the Committee on Foreign Relations and the Committee on Appropriations of the Senate. If the committee does not report the resolution within 15 legislative days, it will be discharged and placed on the appropriate calendar for consideration. When a resolution is reported or discharged from further consideration by a committee, any Member of the respective House can move to proceed to its consideration. The motion can be made the day after announcing intention, or immediately if directed by the committee. All points of order against the resolution are waived, and the motion is privileged in the House of Representatives. The motion to proceed to the consideration of a resolution is privileged in the House of Representatives and the Senate, not debatable, and not subject to amendment or postponement. If agreed to, the respective House immediately considers the resolution without interruption. Debate is limited to 2 hours, divided equally between supporters and opponents, with no amendments allowed. Following the debate on a resolution, a vote on final passage shall occur. Appeals on Chair decisions regarding resolution procedures shall be decided without debate. Following the debate on a resolution, a vote on final passage shall occur. Appeals on Chair decisions regarding resolution procedures shall be decided without debate. If one House receives a resolution from the other House, it shall not be referred to a committee and may only be considered for final passage. The vote on final passage in the receiving House shall be on the resolution from the other House. Upon disposition of a resolution received from the other House, it is no longer in order to consider the resolution that originated in the receiving House. This section is enacted by Congress as part of the rules of each House, applicable only to the procedure for resolutions described in subsection (a). It recognizes the constitutional right of either House to change rules relating to its procedure. (g) Legislative Day Defined.--For the purposes of this section, a "legislative day" is defined as any calendar day when either House is in session.
